Co-design credit goes to my friend, Sarah Watters

Do your prints have shifts?

Is your filament tugging on the spool?

Do you think there may be a better way? Now there is.

This holder works with all types of spools with wide flanges, spools with narrow edges.

The double bearings allow the narrow spools to ride in the gap between the two bearings. This helps with keeping the spool centered.

One side of the holder is cut out to allow for small spools that are full of filament. Just flip the holder around to put the cutout on the inside and you are golden. On the big spools this isn't an issue.

I printed these 100% fill.

Parts

  1. print two holders. one for each side of the spool.
  2. 8 x 608 bearings. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBGTK6?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00
  3. 12 x M8 flat washers
  4. 4 x M8 bolts and nuts. The bolts need to be 35mm long.

Installation

  • slide bolt into base then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • bearing onto bolt then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • bearing onto bolt then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • slide bolt into other side of base then
  • attach nut to bolt

I put washers on the outside of the base too, but you don't need to do that. Also, my bolts were 45mm, because that is what I had on hand.

I designed this for a new pair of Sony MDR-ZX110NC noise-canceling headphones that I bought for a recent trip. My old phones got crushed in my computer bag, and I didn't want the same thing to happen to these.

I took inspiration fro many of the features of this thing from UroBen's "Toolbox for miniature tools".

I printed the prototype with ABS, at 20% infill.

Use pieces of raw 1.75mm material as the hinge pins. I cleaned up the holes with a #52 machinist's drill bit, which leaves them just slightly smaller than the material.

The small holes on the inside of each half will accept 3/16" neodymium magnets, to hold the case closed. The hole in the top half is 3/16" deep, and the one in the bottom is 1/2". Make sure you have the magnets oriented the right way, before you press them in.

I get my magnets from https://www.kjmagnetics.com

comments.text: Great case.  Two suggestions: 1) it's just too hard to push the headphone cable into that narrow storage channel, especially if you're in any kind of hurry.  I think it'd be easier if that was just a large opening that you could stick the bundled cable into.  And (2) as an alternative to magnets, a loop on the end of both pieces would allow something more secure, like a twist tie, to be used in instances where the case might otherwise just pop open.

title: Removable Arm for Lulzbot Mini, no hardware required!

description.text:
This removable arm is a modified version of the original arm designed by https://www.thingiverse.com/DrazzticAction/about (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:773666). The arm design required the purchase of additional metal parts from a third party company. Unsatisfied with that course of action, I designed this arm to use a close-fitting square peg and socket to lock the pieces together. I recommend using super glue to permanently connect the two pieces. The smaller portion of the arm is a modified version of the model by https://www.thingiverse.com/garfong/about(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:876823)

This is the first model I've uploaded. Please feel free to give feedback!

each piece is designed to be printed alone. The larger of the two will need to be rotated diagonally to print on a lulzbot mini bed. after they are printed, simply superglue them together and insert into the removable arm slot (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:756064)

author: soldierkaska

title: RGB LED sensor & IR Blaster Housing

description.text: This is a housing to fit the sensor from a RGB LED remote control system. There is also a space for Infrared LED to operate the controller using a home automation system (which is what this is being used for). The IR LED is hidden and cannot interfere with other controllers in the same room. In the instructions are a list of where I got all the materials from to make this. You will need to cut off the remote sensor and solder on some connectors to make the system much easier to fit.

List Of Materials Below
RBG LED Controller http://www.amazon.co.uk/Remote-Control-Controller-Light-Strip/dp/B004IJFAMW/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1439764008&sr=8-1&keywords=rgb+led+remote

Infrared Blaster LED http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/10-x-Infrared-IR-LED-5mm-940nm-IR-1st-Class-Postage/301349606602?_trksid=p2045573.c100033.m2042&_trkparms=aid%3D111001%26algo%3DREC.SEED%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D33017%26meid%3D582b13b2f6424a1a933f1d521b2600b8%26pid%3D100033%26rk%3D2%26rkt%3D3%26mehot%3Dag%26sd%3D111744484185

3 wire connectors for remote control sensor http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/131547464582?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

2 wire connectors for IR blaster LED. (Please note you may need to fit an in line resistor to this LED depending on how you are controlling it!) http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/111695647837?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=410709663438&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

You will also need a decent soldering iron, a hot melt glue gun or some superglue (to fix the IR blaster into the housing) and some heat shrink tubing to make a nice neat job of it.

  1. Cut off the remote sensor from the controller
  2. Cut away the heat shrink around the end of the sensor (it wont fit in the housing with it attached) and put a small piece of heat shrink on the middle connection. This will insulate it from the 2 outer connections.
  3. Strip wires and feed into the housing from the top so the wires come out of the bottom of the housing, the actual sensor is a snug fit but does fit with a little push in.
  4. Solder the 3 wire connector plug onto the 3 wires from the sensor (you did take notice of what way round they were when you cut them off didn't you, as all the wires are the same colour!!)
  5. Solder the socket end of the connector onto the controller sensor wire you did take notice of what way round they were when you cut them off didn't you, as all the wires are the same colour!!).
  6. Solder the 2 wire plug onto the IR Blaster LED, protect the connections with heat shrink tubing right up the LEDS.
  7. Push the IR LED into the from the back side and fix into place with either a hot melt glue gun or some superglue.
  8. Connect the socket end of the IR Blaster connection to the automation system you are using, remember to fit a resistor in line if needed.
  9. That's it just drill a hole into whatever you are fixing the housing onto and connect up.

The housing you see in the photos were printed using ABS plastic and then smoothed in an acetone vapour bath, the smoothing and the shine makes them look like commercial product.

Enjoy!!

description.text:
This is a modular set to create ground level or elevated oil / chemical pipelines.

UPDATED - 8/22: ALL PARTS REVISED! Reworked the sleeve and casing visual design. Added curve, terminus, ground and raised versions of all pipe parts, elevation change segment, long straight pipe, and Y junction. Should be everything you need to pump black gold around your battlefield. :D

This modular set is a preview of a full model pack of the Colmar chemical plant (Pyre Light). Visual design inspired by MechWarrior 2 building models. Originally designed for 6mm BattleTech (1/285), using 1 hex = 1.75" (1.5in with .125" gutter, similar to HeroScape terrain). Can be scaled to fit other game scales.

If working in mm in your slicing software, scale the .STL by 25.4.

Feedback welcome - please comment!

Multiply scale by 25.4 if working in mm.

Designed for single-extruder .5mm ABS filament. Object is manifold with minimized undercuts and should print successfully with any thermoplastic filament extrusion, powder substrate (3DSystems / zCorp), or similar additive process.

Not suitable for small children.

This model set is a work in progress and files are subject to small or large changes without notice.

description.text:
Parts to mechanically couple an E3Dv6 hot end in place of your stock Budaschnozzle hot end for a Lulzbot TAZ printer. [Now you can print with 1.75mm filament!]

Note: If you update your TAZ to handle the Hexagon extruder (namely, adding a fan cable and upgrading the firmware), you have all the wires you need. Plus the Hexagon and the E3Dv6 both use the same thermister. Now I'm able to swap back and forth between Hexagon and E3Dv6 with a little plugging/unplugging, slicer profiles, and of course z-height home tuning.

It is really four pieces, but in three files. Print the flat pieces flat against the platform, and the other piece, "pc1" on its long side.

Remove your Budaschnozzle.

You will need to drill a small indentation in the bottom of your extruder mount to make room for the little piece of plastic atop the E3Dv6 hot end. [Alternately, make the flat piece taller by a mm or so.]

Assemble adapter as shown. Trim/shave parts as necessary. The fit should be firm, but there shouldn't be any warping from stress.

Reassemble the extruder mount. You will not need any additional screws/bolts/nuts.

Be very careful about homing the TAZ, especially the Z direction, but even X/Y can get you if it homes directly onto the platform mount at the corner.

Adjust your slicer settings accordingly.
Holder for a 21mm (OD) glass slide. Might have to make it a bit stronger yet.
Printed at 0.2 mm with 100% infill for strength.

description.text:
I bought an ancient Kirby vacuum cleaner for cheap (you know, the ones that can survive a direct nuclear strike and keep working). Problem is it came with no hoses.
.
My idea was to print an adapter that would allow me to use a surplus hose from a dead vacuum instead.
.
I haven't yet tried to print this thing, so some adjustment may still be necessary.
You'll probably want to download the .scad file and tweak the first two sizes to fit your replacement hose.

description.text: It is really cool that you can take simple geometric figures (rectangles, pyramids and cones) and turn them into something really amazing

This was my first time using TinkerCAD, so I took lessons on how to use the basic controls. Then I figured out how to make the shapes so they were hollow and would make a mold. From there, I made a simple castle (the base and towers) and then added multiple floors, putting spires around the edges to give it an unwelcoming feeling (and make it look cooler!). Then I added stairs.

description.text: The refrigerator came without a grate in the water dispense area so I created one for it.

This is a pig themed derby car body I made for with my oldest daughter.

The opening in the middle will hold a lego character. In this case a Lego Friends. You will have to let you kid paint it to get such a nice look.

There are 2 versions the regular has all 4 tires at an equal height, the "lifted tire" version has one of the front tires .100" higher than the others. The theory there is less rotational inertia, will allow the car to go faster.

There are 2 holes that run about 2/3 the length in the back, I added steel rods in there to get my mass up and have my center of mass closer to the back wheels.

I printed is only about 15-20% infill. This made it way under our weight limit and then I added the weight where I wanted it.

The tail is 22 AWG solid core wire. I just drilled a hole and hot glued it in.

description.text:
I thought that a peristaltic pump is a better option for paste extruders than some that I have seen. Update: Added hotends, and added a hole for the mounting plate so it will fit correctly on stepper motors.

Note I have NOT made this, I believe it will work but don't know for sure.

I'm designer for shapeways here: https://www.shapeways.com/designer/jonathanmarch/hire-me

Print: Mounting (you can design your own easily), Base, Rotor and Top

Also print a hotend of your choice .5, .75, 1, 1.5, or 2mm

You will need support for the base but should be fine with everything else

Assembly should be self explanatory just refer to the image.

8xM3 screws are needed

4xM3 nuts are needed

Whatever length of 2mm ID, 4mm OD, bowden tube

3x608ZZ bearing (the most common bearing I believe)
22mm OD 8mm ID 7mm height

--You may have to glue the bowden tubing in so it doesn't move.

description.text:
This is a streamlined derby car I did for middle daughter.

The hole in the top middle was so we cold add pennies to dial in the weight on the official track scale.

There are 2 versions the regular has all 4 tires at an equal height, the "lifted tire" version has one of the front tires .100" higher than the others. The theory there is less rotational inertia, will allow the car to go faster.

There are 3 holes that run about 2/3 the length in the back, I added 1/4-20 socket head cap screws in there to get my mass up and have my center of mass closer to the back wheels.

I printed is only about 15-20% infill. This made it way under our weight limit and then I added the weight where I wanted it.

I added washers into the figure 8 cutout in the bottom to keep the CG low.

title: Ninja Turtle themed derby race car

description.text:
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle Van for derby races.

This is a 2 piece design with a van body shell and then a base. This allowed me to add lights and an arduino to the van so it had blinking lights.

There are 2 versions of the base the regular has all 4 tires at an equal height, the "lifted tire" version has one of the front tires .100" higher than the others. The theory there is less rotational inertia, will allow the car to go faster.

The headlights support 10mm LEDs and the taillights support 5mm LEDs. I did white for the headlights and red for the taillights, it looked really silck.

The body shell should snap onto the base. It wasn't perfect on the first try but close enough, I think I used a bit of hot glue in the slots of the base to dial in my fit.

description.text:
Thought I would practice with Sketchup and create some bling for the printer.

Motorcycle can be found;
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:364675
Cover may need to be scaled to fit your motor.

Clip-on brackets allow for temporary support of light weight items. I am using them to support my tomato seedlings. The aluminum foil tray is tie-wrapped to the triangular brackets.

The brackets are sized for .625" thick fence, so you may need to modify them for thicker fence material.
I printed them in low res, 10% fill in makerware on my FF creator pro using ABS. I printed two brackets at once since I had sized them so that two would fit on one build plate.

"Haniwa" is Japanese clay figures made in 3rd to 6th centuries AD.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haniwa

Especially we used the one below as reference.
http://www.tnm.jp/uploads/r_collection/LL_32.jpg

They are actually stamp body and express "OK" and "ReTake (not OK)" by both their look and stamp itself.

The stamp parts are exchangeable by pin.

A school project with Miss Kajiwara.

Also, you can buy finished product from here (Japan only, sorry).
https://minne.com/items/2343887

I am using DaVinci 1.0 3D printer by XYZ printing.

Layer pitch is 0.3mm.
Normal speed and normal shell thickness.

No raft. No support.
With stick paste(Tombow, Shiwanashi PIT).

200 minutes to print. 30 minutes for shaping, constructing and sanding.
20m for ABS.

Other parts,
2 pins (ø3*10, SUS)

How to use pins?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNg1lNYXcFk

In case of traditional machining, making accurate pin-holes on object is not so easy thing,
especially if the object is small, has irregular shape or the pin-hole is angled.
Because it needs additional assembling jigs to fix.

However, in case of 3D printing, it is pretty easy.
It does not need any other cost, except adding holes in 3D data.

The metal pins are enough accurate, so you can make both type of holes lock and roose easily.
Also it is much more strong than 3D printing materials, so you can make thin strut or axle.
Also it is enough cheap so you can bury under objects, or glue it.

Of course you can use screws. Actually screws are more usual in real world.
However you have to tap holes, you can not make loose screw or you can not joint objects face by face because it needs driver.

note. You need "reamer" and "drill chuck" to adjust holes.
This adapter allows you to use the square mount of the factory mount.

Printed in PLA with 0.200mm layers. Requires 2.5mm bolts with a length not to protrude through the top of the plate and contact the Mobius. The holes are quadrants of a 12mm circle. The holes are designed as 2mm to allow threading to 2.5mm. I used an actual tap to thread the holes, but this could be accomplished with a bolt just as easily. Drill clearance holes in the plate you are mounting to for the 2.5mm bolt.

Repair the body's largest organ with this snazzy device straight from Dr.Bashir's Sickbay!

* Modified by thinning out the model and changing the grips. **

Uploaded second refined version closer to screen used prop.

2015-11-28 Redesign and re-splice to address printing issues

PLEASE re-scale this model using picture reference. The model is too big and need a re-size to your preference.

Ring-shaped bobbin holder.

Completely customizable. Would like to add some sort mechanism to keep the bobbins in place (magnet in the bottom of the groove? some sort of ridge running along the top so the bobbins "snap in"?).

Pictures show a print with an inner radius of 4cm.

With the default settings, it should hold about 30 10mm-high bobbins, since from 2 * π * r ≈ x * 10 with r = 50 follows x ≈ 30 (31.415, to be precise).

(More accurately: 2 * π * r = 31.415 * 10 ⇔ r = 50. I planned to fit ~30 bobbins anyway, and liked that π gets canceled out instead of having a real number for diameter.)

I'm using mine just as it was when I took it out of the printer: I'm surprised that your print is rough. I'm even more surprised that you claim the bobbins to fit in some sections of the donut but not others—have you taken the time to properly calibrate your printer?

title: Wanhao Duplicator  i3 front blower fan mount and shroud

description.text:
These parts adapt a blower type fan for use on the front of the machine. The shroud snaps into place and was printed with PET while the rest was done in PLA.

NEW VERSION: HEX

** Warning - On long builds I've melted this shroud pretty badly where its close to the heater block. You might want to put some aluminum foil tape or kapton on the inside to prevent this if you are going to use it. I'm working on a redesign. Thanks for your interest. ***

I've redesigned the shroud to have six outlets near the nozzle but pointing down only onto the extrudate. These are spaced apart so as to allow the nozzle to be visible from several angles as well. Plus it looks cool. No pun intended.

This is the fan I used:

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MJU6JR2?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00

OLD VERSION

Don't print the shroud with supports.

The holes are a little small and will need to be drilled out for M3 and M4 screws.

This is the fan I used:

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MJU6JR2?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00

The shroud is an adaptation of a design by delukart.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 (Pruisa i3)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.18mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The area of the shroud that needs supporting is the horizontal upper section of the female socket that mates up to the elbow and the arches within. Do not autosupport! Your software may put supports inside the cooler which cannot be removed.

The only area of the elbow that needs to be supported is the horizontal underside of the male part of the socket and the arches within.

I suggest PET for the shroud and use cooling (regardless of material) for at least the top half of the print for the nozzles.

Once supports are cleaned out, superglue the elbow to the shroud. It should be a fairly tight fit.

Depending on how your heating block is oriented, a corner may rest close enough to the shroud to melt it locally. I suggest taping the inside of the shroud with kapton or aluminum tape just to be safe.

The holes are a little small in the mounting bracket and will need to be drilled out for M3 and M4 screws. The screw on the left side goes in from the underside.
Once supports are removed, a little filing or scraping may be needed to get the elbow to fully seat into the shroud.

description.text:
Open Dungeon door made from old D&D plaster molds scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner and mixed with qubist's Pocket Dungeon Door using netfabb software.

Using to make assembled printable dungeon scenery for D&D.

This is a co-invention, TheMegaCorp ( http://www.thingiverse.com/TheMegaCorp ) and I worked together to invent the ultimate simple build platforms for our Prusas. These platforms are cut from 1/4" MDF, with a top and bottom part that snap together tightly. This allows you to have one heated platform with kapton for printing ABS and one with polycarbonate for PLA, or whatever combinations you need! TheMegaCorp added a hole in the bottom plate, so you can now access your belt clips and tighten your belt without removing anything!!! GENIUS! You can buy every part of this except the heated PCB in a single trip to Home Depot. Ideas for improvements:
  • add magnets to make a solid connection even after the boltholes eventually wear down.
  • get a better model than TMC... what's Vanna White doing now?

It probably helps that TMC and I both have slightly oversized Prusa builds. 1) Measure the actual distance between your triangle ends, and subtract a 1/4" margin. Cut a rectangle of 1/4" MDF that's 5.5" x your distance. This is your 'squashed frog'. Then cut at least three squares of your distance x your distance. These are your lower platform and two upper platforms. 2) Make a stack of the squashed frog, and the three cut squares. Label their orientation with A and B. Also label which are the top platforms and which is the bottom. Make sure they are very neatly aligned, then use a clamp to hold them firmly together. Mark a spot to drill 3/8" in from each corner of the squashed frog. 3) Use a 1/8" drill (for M3 hardware - sorry for the bizarre mix of English and Metric) and drill the four holes you just marked. If you're not using M3 hardware, select a drill bit size that allows your bolts to slide through the hole cleanly, but with no slop. Drill through the whole stack. 4) Remove the squashed frog from the stack. Take your heated bed PCB (assuming you have one) and use it as a template to mark mounting holes on the remaining stack. Use the same drill from step 3 to drill these holes though the entire stack. 5) Now break up the rest of the stack. Mark four holes in the center of the BOTTOM PLATFORM, make a square that will allow you to cut out a hole to reach your squashed frog belt clips. Use a large drill to drill these holes in the BOTTOM PLATFORM only. Use a jigsaw to connect the holes and cut out a squareish hole to reach your belt. 6) In the BOTTOM PLATFORM, re-drill though the 4 heated PCB holes with a 1/4" drill (This fits M3 hardware - use a drill that fits your bolt head snugly (not TIGHT, just snug). 7) In the TOP PLATFORMS, re-drill through the 4 squashed frog holes with the same size (1/4") drill. Now you are ready to assemble it! Use the photos for examples of how to build your hardware stack. The important part is, the bolt heads will fit into the larger holes, giving you sunk bolts, and also a firm mechanical connection between the plates. If you want an even better connection, thread a nut onto your bolts first, so they stand up higher, as TheMegaCorp has done in the photos here. The fender washers in-between the springs are only there for style points, they do not accomplish anything.
  • HEATED PCB TOP TIPS/NOTES:
  • We are using the heated PCB from Ultimachine. At $50, it's quite a bargain.
  • The insulation we put underneath is ZOLTEK PYRON. We could probably run these straight on the MDF, but ZOLTEK PYRON is worth it for the name alone! You can get these sheets at Home Depot, sold as a FLAME PROTECTOR for plumbers to solder over.

  • The aluminum is the very skinny aluminum sheeting available at Home Depot. I'd like to replace it with something more solid but this seems to work great in the interim. You can machine this with a jigsaw and a drill. Easy.

  • POLYCARB TOP TIPS/NOTES:
  • We are using a narrow sheet of polycarbonate from Home Depot.
  • We should have cut it with drilled holes to match the heated PCB size, but we cut it before we came up with this dastardly plan, which is why we've mounted it down with washers.

title: On the fly bed level test

description.text: Did you spend $20 on overpriced bed glass yet still find little quirks in the first  layer of your print? Got your bed corners dead perfect and still got an issue from print to print? Try this test to see if there is variance in the glass.  This test will also allow you to make adjustments during the print if you have a toolless setup like I do (thumb knobs recommended for ease of the tiniest change) I have found this to be a great asset. Watch the print width of the first layer print to see where your problem areas are and adjust as it prints.  No need to let it go to the end. the first layer is the important one.  Let it run to see problems in your retraction and restarts.

author: Phinnegan

description.text:
My sand spirograph brings math from your school desk to the beach.

About the design:
Modeled in Blender with the original Spirograph toy in mind that I used to have when I was little. I tried to keep the list of printed parts minimal by creating a two-gear system instead of a more complex scissor extension arm. A unique feature of my design is the guide wheel that supports the tracing gear to keep it level and from falling into the sand while still allowing the gear to rotate

Assembly: (same for both large and small designs) See video for visual
1.) Assemble the tracing gear with the tracing pins at any of the four holes into the top face of the gear. You may use any combination of the pinholes.
2.) Stack the base, guide wheel, and then tracing gear.

How To Use:
Large sand spirograph
1.) Find moist sand and make a flat surface with it. Sprinkle a thin layer of dry sand on the top for a more contrasting result.
2.) Place the sand spirograph on top of the sand surface, then turn the tracing gear by holding the gear's handle and guiding it in a circular pattern.
3.) After making as many revolutions as you like, lift the entire sand spirograph off the sand to see your spirograph creation.

Small sand spirograph
1.) Using the blank castle mold and fine, moist sand, create a blank puck shaped castle. Sprinkle a thin layer of dry sand on the top for a more contrasting result.
2.) Place the small spirograph assembly over the sand "puck."
3.) Turn the tracing gear by holding the gear's handle and guiding it in a circular pattern.
4.) After making as many revolutions as you like, lift the entire sand spirograph off the sand to see your spirograph creation.

Spirograph background info:
The spirograph is a toy that produces mathematical roulette curves. My design creates a hypotrochoid roulette curve with the parametric equations:
     x(θ) = (R - r) cos(θ) + d cos((R - r) / r)
     y(θ) = (R - r) sin(θ) - d cos((R - r) / r)
where r is the radius of the inner tracing gear.
R is the radius of the fixed gear on the base of the assembly.
d is the distance of the tracing pin from the center of the inner tracing gear.

The spirograph was invented by mathematician Bruno Abakanowicz around 1881 and was used to calculate the area delimited (bounded) by curves. Drawing toys using gears started to become popular around 1908 when the Sears catalog advertised The Marvelous Wondergraph. The Spirograph toy brand was started in 1965 by Denys Fisher and named 1967 Toy of the Year. It was a 2014 Toy of the Year finalist.

Assembly: (same for both large and small designs) See video for visual
1.) Assemble the tracing gear with the tracing pins at any of the four holes into the top face of the gear. You may use any combination of the pinholes.
2.) Stack the base, guide wheel, and then tracing gear.
https://youtu.be/xREpIZMOoRM

How To Use:
Large sand spirograph
1.) Find moist sand and make a flat surface with it. Sprinkle a thin layer of dry sand on the top for a more contrasting result.
2.) Place the sand spirograph on top of the sand surface, then turn the tracing gear by holding the gear's handle and guiding it in a circular pattern.
3.) After making as many revolutions as you like, lift the entire sand spirograph off the sand to see your spirograph creation.

Small sand spirograph
1.) Using the blank castle mold and fine, moist sand, create a blank puck shaped castle. Sprinkle a thin layer of dry sand on the top for a more contrasting result.
2.) Place the small spirograph assembly over the sand "puck."
3.) Turn the tracing gear by holding the gear's handle and guiding it in a circular pattern.
4.) After making as many revolutions as you like, lift the entire sand spirograph off the sand to see your spirograph creation.

description.text:
I changed a few things on the falchion to make it more to my liking. The sword is based on pictures from the Knights of Iris book and from various pictures online.

To print the sword, I cut the design in half (horizontal plane) and then in 3 pieces length-wise since it is a 40" sword and I have a 16" wide bed. At the interface between segments, I made V-slices to the stl so that when I go to solder and heat-weld the PLA pieces together, they have the most strength. This worked well for my Ike sword that I printed.

I am open to suggestions for how to make the sword better but may still choose to do it "my way".

author: FRodriguez96

title: Ultimate Spool Holder for M3D Filament

description.text:
This is an external filament holder that fits the small 120mm spools. The double bearings allow the narrow spools to ride in the gap between the two bearings. This helps with keeping the spool centered.

You can print bolts and nuts here if you want.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

I printed this at 100% fill.

Parts

  1. print one holder
  2. 8 x 608 bearings. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBGTK6?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00
  3. 12 x M8 flat washers
  4. 2 x M8 bolts. The bolts need to be 65mm long
  5. 6 x M8 nuts

You can remove the washers between the bearings if you want. It helps reduce friction on the spools without the washers.

Installation

  • slide bolt into base then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • bearing onto bolt then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • bearing onto bolt then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • tighten a nut onto the bolt then
  • tighten another nut onto the bolt then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • bearing onto bolt then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • bearing onto bolt then
  • washer onto bolt then
  • slide bolt into other side of base then
  • attach nut to bolt

I put washers on the outside of the base too, but you don't need to do that.

description.text: In honour of the FairPhone open-design bootcamp I present to you an iPhone 4 case that tells it like it is. My InCase case broke a week ago, and I thought what thingiverse really needed was another iPhone 4 case.

This is a pretty simple design - you can't merge these stl for dualstrusion, as I have built in a .3mm clearance so that there is an interference fit with the letters and the case. This makes for some nice crisp lines between the text.  
I printed this case on a Makerbot Replicator (the wooden one), on a 3M Blue Tape build plate, warmed to 50Â°C... printed in PLA (of course).  
The case is particularly difficult to get off the build plate, as there is so much surface tension- I'd recommend laying a raft (so you don't end up damaging your build plate, lifting a finger nail, or mis-levelling your plate).

author: TheNewHobbyist

description.text:
I basically crammed in as many math related ideas as possible.

King and Queen's Castle- they like to show their power so a model of the equation y=x^2 (power of 2) is built into the castle.

Princess's Tower- The princess is very beautiful so she fittingly has a tower that has many parts that follow the golden ratio. This ratio is approximately 1.618 and has been used in architecture since ancient times as it is said to make things look beautiful. This ratio is determined by a segment A having the same ratio to segment B as B does to A + B.

Prince's House- The prince is a pretty cool dude but he's stuck in the 90's and still uses the word radical to say awesome. His house matches this and is shaped like a radical (square root symbol). There are also some numbers and symbols on top to easily stamp into the sand.

Wall/Moat- The wall is designed after a sine wave(or cosine depending on your view) from 0 to pi. It can also be flipped into a moat with tessellated crocodiles to protect the kingdom.

Dragon Curve Flag- Castle's are medieval and so are dragons soit just made sense to have a flag with the dragon curve on it flying over the kingdom.

Jester's Abstract Die- the Jester is a crazy fellow always thinking of wondrous things, some of which he put onto a die. (There is a normal and flipped one to use as die or display and the other for stamping the sand)

Jester's Schrodinger Shovel- Another of the jester's wild ideas. Though more physics related this double sided shovel displays an alive cat on one end and a dead one on the other to honor Schrodinger's Cat. You'll never know what end your using unless you look!

Triangle Factorial Village- The king and queen needed order in their kingdom but they also wanted a large one as well, so they designed it as a triangle factorial that way half the land would be open for enjoyment and it would always be orderly no matter how large.
print at the scale of your choosing. The larger you go the easier it is to use for sand. all molds print fine.

title: The Castle with the Dragon Tattoo

description.text: I've used solidworks to create a sandcastle--one that includes five levels, a moat, and a dragon. It uses a combination of symmetry, equations (to better establish dimensions), geometry (in the stone walls, square bases, and towers), and oodles of relations (using centerlines and midpoints).

This Thing was made using solidworks. The progression of how it was made can hopefully be seen in the attached files. But in short, it was made using one part. I built five levels off of one base, added in the towers using sketch, and then proceeded to add feature-based details. This included fillets, shells, extruded cuts, filled patterns, and the DRAGON!

Arduped 2 is a tweaked version of David Ultis's Arduped Biped Robot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19594) that includes source code by Gabriel Ro-Bot-X and Kai Neugebauer to make it work. I redesigned the build platform and head sensor and tweaked the feet, but I left the original legs alone because they worked just fine. The OpenSCAD source files for these changes can be found in the zip file called "OpenScad Files with Utils Folder.zip".

Here is a video of it in action: http://youtu.be/PAQJ-nnLGbg

Materials
========

  • Arduino nano
  • 5 x Tower Pro SG90 servos (available on Ebay). You will need the horns and the screws for these as well.
  • 1x Ultrasonic sensor HC-SR04
  • A small on/off rocker switch (should be easy to find on Ebay)
  • 2 x M3 x 25mm screws to mount the servo for the head. M2 screws are actually preferable here as you will have to drill out the servo mount a bit to use M3 screws.
  • 4 x M3 x 12mm screws to mount the servos to the build platform
  • 6 x M3 nuts
  • Hot glue (from a glue gun) or super glue

See instructions for more details

Here are some guidelines to putting the robot together:

  • Print the parts using an infill like 10% to keep them nice and light
  • Attach a switch to the positive (red) side of your power source. I used 2 x 3.7V lipo packs in parallel as it still works with that much power, but basically you need something close to 5V for this to work.
  • Wire up the servos, the HC-SR04 and the Arduino nano to the positive (red) and ground (black) of your power source after the on/off switch.
  • Mount and screw in the the servos as per the pictures. I used hot glue to mount the servos to the feet, but you could use super glue. I also used glue to attach the servo horns to the legs as this worked a bit better than the screws, but the choice is yours. You'll want to cut off the servo mount wings on the feet that are sticking out on the inside as these can catch and cause problems with walking.
  • Wire up the rest to the Arduino nano:
    • Trigger pin of sonic sensor - Pin 12
    • Trigger pin of echo sensor - Pin 11
    • Servo wires (orange) should be connected to the following pins:
      • Left leg - Pin 7
      • Right leg - Pin 10
      • Left foot - Pin 8
      • Right foot - Pin 9
      • Head - Pin 6
  • Open up the Arduino sketch program and import the NewPing library if you don't already have it. In 1.6.5 the menu path is Sketch -> Include Library -> Add .ZIP library.
  • Open up the sketch in "BiPed Arduino Code.zip", extract the contents and rename the folder uBipedino. Then Compile and upload the file to the Arduino Nano.
  • You'll probably have to play with the position of the servo horns on the servo at first to get the correct position for it to walk. But once that is done you should be set.

comments.text:
Hi, I used a similar set of batteries 3.7V lipo packs but they burned 2 of my arduinos, do you know why?
Here are the ones I got: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LK0DY3O?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01

comments.author: hfarrer

comments.text: I'm sorry to hear that. If you are connecting those in serial for a total of 7.4V then you'll want to connect them to the vcc on the Nano so they go through the voltage regulator and not the 5v on the board. However if you are connecting them to the 5v, I suspect it will work with just one of those as mine were 250mah batteries (I see yours are 600mah) and I connected them in parallel. I hope that helps.

title: USB B connector - Round hole adapter

description.text:
I do not like to make square holes for USB connectors.
This adapter and the PCB layout allows you to make a round hole (that's easy) for the adapter and then fit a standard USB-B connector with the small PCB into this.
Its designed as a Press/Snap fit.
To use, you need to connect a wire's from where your current USB connector is, to the small PCB.
You can use this with Arduino, Raspberry or any other bord with USB-B connector.
For the SCAD users the scad source allows to integrate the USB connector press/snap fit into other enclosures or panels.
The connector used is Farnell 1642035 or 1308876

Just import the STL into your slicer and do what ever you normally do.
I use ABS for this print, other materials are not prohibited.
The PCB layout is reproduced using normal processes - and easy to redesign if you need Gerber.

The design is created in SCAD.
SCAD definition for the outer perimeter of the adapter is subtracted with the definition of the USB connector and a holding Clamp is added.
The SCAD is included and you can modify it to match your needs, even use it for other square hole connector's

Parts to facilitate the fabrication of an electrolytic rust removal apparatus.

The first thing to do is go read ToolNut's excellent Instructable found here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Electrolytic-Rust-Removal-aka-Magic/?ALLSTEPS
.
Pay particular attention to the warning about the use of stainless steel.
.
The pictures should be self-explanatory. There are two sets; one for the use of a standard 5 gallon plastic bucket, and another set for the use with a rectangluar plastic tub. Either should scale well.
.
You will need a bucket, pieces of rebar, copper wire, zip ties, adhesive, 1/4-20 nuts, bolts, & washers, alligator clips, small sheet metal screws, and some 1/2 inch Schedule 40 PVC pipe. And a source of electricity (I use an old computer power supply).
.
I used epoxy to attach the rebar supports to the interior of the plastic bucket, but it failed after a few uses. Perhaps silicone caulk would be a better solution, or maybe large neodymium magnets to hold the rebar in place. But use any adhesive you deem appropriate.
.
The part is suspended by heavy wire; this ensures there is no strain on the alligator clips and the electrical connection.
.
If I forgot anything, please leave a note in the comments section.
.
Developed with TinkerCad.
.
It works swell.
.
UPDATE 19-Aug-15: Big changes! Added two new files (newAnode, newCathode) which greatly simplify things. No more sheet metal screws or zip ties; the parts are designed to slide freely along the pipes. The rebar supports are no longer needed; 12g solid copper wire holds the rebar in place nicely. See photos for reference.
.
Time to think about electroplating?

.

description.text: I really wanted one of Iwo's ducted cooling fan ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5756 ), but only had a 40mm fan, so I printed his thing, then made an adapter ring to fit my junk box 40mm fan.

Print Iwo's ducted cooling fan http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5756 then print one of these adaptor plates. It just presses into the top of Iwo's design. You could drop a little acetone onto the join to glue it, but I haven't found the need. I have found a little strip of double sided tape is necessary to keep the whole duct in place on the build platform (can be seen in the photos through the bottom).

comments.text: Thank you for the adapter, for some reason, I don't think I would have thought of this. ;)
comments.author: sockles

comments.text: You're welcome. I'm constantly amazed at what other people invent.
comments.author: sockles

comments.text: So hows the performance? Help in the tip cooling? No more threading?
comments.author: swosho

comments.text: You really need a stepper extruder to kill the threading, and that would be the single best upgrade I made to my system, but the fan is great for solidifying the extruded plastic, particularly PLA. I found that just slowing down the time it took to print a layer created problems with the PLA melting up the extruder stem (so much so that I put a ducted fan there too).

  • 4 zip ties (optional)

    Like these: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__40603__Vibration_Damping_Ball_65g_Bag_of_8_.html

Enjoy!

description.text:
I made myself some DIY 433 dipoles and immediately realised that the center is very fragile. This block remedies that and results in a very strong antenna, it will NOT Break at the center at least. :)

remixed_from.title: Active Cooling Fan Duct v2 for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

description.text:
Carl's Aluminum AluCarriage-dual (http://shop.raffle.ch/shop/alucarriage-dual/) are a great upgrade for Replicator's.

Better cooling is important thing for printing...

Updated: 2015-10-04

New Version V2.2 available

Changes:

  • Fixed cooler air leak
  • Air pressure improvements
  • Compression improvements
  • Added logo

Optimized for:

  • Layer: 0.1-0.15 mm
  • Nozzle: 0.4 mm

Added:

  • Fan: 40x40x10 mm (12/24v)
  • Screw: d=3 mm

Better cooling is important thing for printing...

Print setup (v2.2):

  • Fillament: ABS (240C nozzle + 110C platform)
  • Layer: 0.1-0.15 mm
  • Nozzle: 0.4 mm
  • Speed: ~60 mm/s

!!! Dont use PLA for this thing - because hot-end is near from duct pipes. Themperature near hot-end can rise over 60C and damage PLA. ABS can be heated up to 100C without damage...

description.text:
I wanted to use thing:719230 for my smartphone - and had the idea to combine it with the universal tripod mount (thing:46378), which I printed a while ago.

The first try, with the mount right in the middle, showed that even an iPhone5 is a bit to big for the rig.
So I changed my design an moved the mount to the front, constructing a foot, making the rig selfstanding again. Now the gap between the phone and the handle is a bit wider. It would be a good idea to extend the top and bottom bar a bit more - on my CTC annother 1.5 cm would be possible.

The biggest advantage - besides the good grip - of such a rig is the possibility to mount accessory, as an extra light or an external microphone. Therefor I added an quarter inch thread to the top.

Print one of each except the grip which you need two times.
Print the grips and the bottomslot with support.

Uses
4x M8x50 cap head bolts and nylon nuts for the rig itself
4x 4-40 x 1/2 Socket Head Cap Screw for the universal mount
1x 2.5" x 1/4" OD Spring for the universal mount

If you want to mount accessories you have to get an 1/4 inch to 1/4 inch adapter (for tripods etc.), screw it in (use pliers, the thread might be tight) and add an hotshoe adapter.

For further instructions look them up here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:719230
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46378/#instructions

The original was by the look a screw driver through the card board box that a spool comes in there by bingo a spool holder,,,,,so simple but yet very clever. I reckon its a sign of a good designer.

My remix is incase you don't have a spare screw driver or just want to print that rod so here it is. "i've not had a chance to print my remix out yet,,,please post a pic if you print it thanks."

Be sure to check out the original below.
Attribution to the original designer, "i'm impressed, your a good designer".
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:971591
quadrcopter fpv 260

UPDATE (OCT-11-2015): Added a new modular motor's attachment (I recommend this instead of the old one, this is more robust) .Added a new clip separator (Z-Scale it if needed) to support different laser modules without reprinting/redesigning existing pieces. (Added due to laser module change)
UPDATE (AUG-20-2015): Even more pics!!
UPDATE (AUG-19-2015): Added mounts for fans & more pics!!

This is a pin mount for a laser module onto a nema17 motor. The module is attached to the external laser pin via some screws. You have to drill the holes depending on the laser module you are using or edit the freecad sources to edit the external pin. Once done this you simply attach the laser module to the rail-like pin (up-down). The support is attached to the motor via a single M3 screw connecting with the extruder mount. The plain part in the front of the support is used to connect a cable chain and fan for the laser module. Common laser modules can be attached easily. Just check out your printer limits/endstops. This thing is tested on a L3K extruder. The laser module is a TTL driven 2W 450nm, but in the pics is just at 1% power to not disturb the camera. I have customized Marlin to add support for laser M03/M05 commands and new menus to control the laser from the LCD. Driver TTL controlled by the PWM pin 44 on arduino.

Happy laser CNC'ing!!!

I know there are much better (with threaded tops) traps out there but this was one of my first prints so I thought I'd throw it up.
Basic fruit fly trap - works with most wide mouth canning jars in conjunction with the canning band.
[EDIT}
Ok so after employing my own trap two things became apparent to me:

  1. There is too much surface area around the opening to the trap. They flies are perfectly happy just hanging out on top.
  2. The reason I think they are perfectly happy to hang out on top is because I printed mine with a low fill factor leaving it quite permeable to the aromas of the fermentation happening below.

I have uploaded a new polygonal design that eliminates most of that surface area up top. I went with a polygon because it's a faster print for my machine (Micro 3D) and at the moment my machine doesn't like circles so much (backlash issues I have yet to solve).

I do have a round version if you'd prefer that.

This is a computer-style fan designed as a concept to show the kind of geometries you can produce with a typical 3D printer.

To make this fan you need to download two STL files and acquire two common ball bearings (4x18x12mm).

The 3D-printed parts consist contain some challenging geometries such as steep ang extreme angles, as well as perfectly flat surfaces which are not printable without the use of support structures.

If you are note familiar with 3D-printing using support structures, settings optimisation, etc, then this is the perfect model for you to step up to the next level!

By Creative Tools

author: Flubber

description.text:
I made an OpenSCAD script to generate designs for roller bearings.
The support must be printed with a soluble material, I used HIPS and ABS but you could use PVA.

The attached renders show the internal workings of the bearing and the support material.

The print is quite difficult and I have not yet had a completely working bearing. See more about the roller design process at http://blog.laserphile.com

The included STLs are sized to suit a spool holder with an 8mm rod and 31mm outer diameter. If you use the STLs included you must print with 0.3mm extrusion width and 0.2mm layer height, this is to do with the tight tolerances.

If your printer does not match the above print settings or you want to change the size of the bearing then download the OpenSCAD script and modify the variables to suit your printer and desired bearing size. There are detailed instructions in the script.

In order to print the soluble support alongside the solid material you must load both STLs into the same print. I used slic3r and had individual settings for the support material and solid material. You should use the following settings: 

For soluble support:  
    -Extruder                       soluble material (HIPS)  
    -Top solid layers               1  
    -Solid bottom layers            0  
    -Perimeters                     0  
    -Solid infill threashold area   1mm^2   

For bearing:  
    -Extruder                       solid material (ABS)  
    -Top solid layers               3  
    -Solid bottom layers            3  
    -Perimeters                     5

author: trevorboultwood

description.text:
This is a simple filament guide designed to be attached to the 8mm frame of the Prusa i3. The mounting holes dimensions are based on preexisting holes in the frame of my Migbot Prusa i3.

You'll want a 624 bearing (and M3 bolt) for the slot that the filament passes through, however if you don't have one I've included a printable bushing-type replacement. Right now I'm using this type of bushing design in a belt tensioner and it has been reliable so far.

I've included a blank frame plate to allow customization, as well as my own version I made for my printer.

Please see instructions for optimal print.

And sorry for the bad screenshots lol.

I highly recommend using a raft when printing, or at the very least a brim to keep it from falling over mid-print. You'll need to enable Support 'Everywhere' if using Cura.

I designed this file to print with minimal support, and you'll see in the screenshot that with Support enabled 'Everywhere', only the Bearing slot needs support (shown in blue).

I'd post a picture of it made but my cell phone broke and I have no other camera, but please feel free to post a picture if you make this.

This was designed to allow you to use Velcro straps to fasten the holder to a round leg tripod or pole. You can then either use more Velcro strap or adhesive Velcro to mount the battery to the holder.

Originally designed for LiPo RC batteries but it has other uses I'm sure.

There is a large and small version as well as the Design Spark Mechanical files.

Czechoslovakian main tank in 1938. Captured by german and used as Pz35(t) against alies.

Tank is printed from several parts and then glued together. Size of original model is aprox. 1:40. I myself printed it 2:1 and colored it with model paints.
Turret can rotate and main gun can change elevation if completed right.
Biggest pain are tracks. There is plenty of support to remove.
To complete tover, u need glue machinegunn into tover. Main gun needs 2x "kolik_dela" inside, before u insert it to turret. "rozperka_dela" is then glued into main gun to hold these 2 pins inside of turret.
Both tracks (left and right side) are simply glued to hull.
Turred holds in hull with pin completed from "spojka_veze_a" and 4 pieces "spojka veze_b ".

This compensator is made to fit a 3mm glass bed so that the bed does not need to be re-levelled upon removing and adding the glass bed.

This compensator fits around the back bars of the printer so that when the Z axis is homed, it provides a 3mm space between the end stopper and the bed.

To make sure it does not break your glass on first install, remove the glass bed and install the compensator. Home the Z axis and the glass bed should slide in between the nozzle and bed nicely. Should it not, then only minor adjustments should be needed.

Iv used mine for 2 months now, with many hours of printing and has not failed me yet. Let me know how it works with your printer and if there are any improvements you would like. Enjoy!

title: Tea Bag Stand

description.text:
I love tea.. And consume lot of it.. I usually use a tea bag more than once..

Since I dont like to leave it in the cup because it changes the taste of the Tea. Hence, I decided to make a stand where I can hang the tea bag for re using it..

Thought I would share it for someone like me..

While printing I would advise you to check if the support is generated on the top, where I would roll the string of the tea bag.. Lot of softwares aren't automatically able to do that..

I have made that insets so that not a large surface touches your tea bag since you would like to reuse it.
And I made that as a separate thing so that you dont need to have support for printing it.
Also, in that way the insets that will be touching your Tea bag can be made of PLA which is advisable according to food standards.

author: ZimboSlice

description.text: My friend Ricardo designed this speed bike frame and we printed it in 1:5 scale. Just a cool model to fabricate.

The design was made in Solidworks 2013 (file included). IÂ´ve modeled the support structures for the rear wheel triangles. I believe theyÂ´re very light and efficient for this part, a lot lighter than supports from skeinforge or slic3r.
  • Print both sides in different runs. The build is ~172x148mm (rotate parts in table to get the best configuration).
    IÂ´ve used 0.2mm layers. Each part is 10 grams and took here 50min to print in my Ecksbot.
  • Remove the support structures is easy but take some time and a very sharp blade.
  • Glue parts together and enjoy your model!

Highly detailed model, 85 cm. high (true 1:400 scale) designed directly from the original blueprints. The model was built from 52 pieces, most of them 3D printed flat and glued together. Some of the pieces need light thermo-forming to adjust the curvature of the assembly and avoid printing with support.
All pieces of the model can be printed in a 20x20 cm. printing bed, but if you have a larger printing bed the model can be scaled up to build a huge and beautiful tower.

The prototype was printed in PLA using 0.2 layer height and printing speeds between 20 and 40 mm/s depending on the detail of the particular piece. All pieces print without support. The model is very easy to print and fun to assembly together.

description.text: DIY replacement feet for unibody Macbook Pro

• Just print it with flexible PLA (or ABS).
  • Unscrew bottom panel from macbook pro.
  • Remove current plastics in feet holes.
  • Clean it. (Maybe alcohol)
  • Put some glue on the printed feets and put them in place.
  • Remove glue on the inside of the bottom panel.
  • I also heated a screw driver and melted the dots in the inside for extra stability.
    • Good luck!

title: mobile phone holder for BMW e90

description.text:
As I bought my car there was an existing holder for a special mobile navigationsystem. The reasons for this project is simple: no more update for it!
So I checked the possibilities to create a holder for my mobile phone and I disassembled the old one. After some measuring of the basic plate (picture 2 and 3) of the dashboard I started to design it in Fusion.
The idea is to install two separated parts (you need only 4 countersunk screws with nuts M3 x 20 to fixed them together). The "bed" (I hope that the right word for it) is exchangeable.
At the moment I created a version for a Samsung Galaxy S4 but it has some issues with the camera and the volume up button.
Next version has an USB connector in the middle of the basic holder, and it's black.

Update 2018-01-14: After some years I found the time to update this project with a bed for the Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge with a bumper like this:
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00SV635BG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s01?ie=UTF8&language=en_GB&psc=1
Pictures will follow (It's hard to show the holder with the mobile phone if you have just one camera :-D )

The material is ABS and the current version contains a lot of bars to rigid the structure against vibrations and heavy hits during driving.

During the firt printing I used a lot of support material for the basic part (for the next I'm going to avoid it). The bed has only in the corner some support.

The temperature is for the extruder 235°C to 230°C and for the bed 120°C. Thickness of each layer is 0.2 mm.

If you like it you can downloaded in other formats under following links:
basic part: http://a360.co/1hj6SG6
bed for S4: http://a360.co/1UOKd2m

You want to improve something? Then you're welcome to modify it. Please leave me a short message and I'm going to send you an invitation.

title: Piggyback adapter for Synta/Vixen telescope finder bracket

description.text:
The prototype will be printed next week, but as it isn't a complicated or particularly failure-prone component I went ahead and uploaded.

The only other part necessary for this adapter is a 1/4-20 screw. It's a piggyback adapter useful for attaching guide scopes, cameras, Skyscouts or other accessories to a telescope equipped with the ubiquitous Synta style dovetail shoe. Please note, this will NOT work with refractors in which the finder bracket is integrated into the focuser assembly. This is because the adapter is designed to be loaded from the opposite direction into the bracket with a large stop designed to prevent the accessory from sliding out the back and onto the ground if the screw is slightly loose, something which has always bothered me about the design of Synta finder shoe accessories.

author: malcD

description.text:
Parametric Hollow Plug

Just change the Diam. Interno mesurement and it will ajust acordingly in SolidWorks 2014.

There are awesome some ready made stl with the outside diameter in the name, if you don´t have solidwork to edit it, please let me know and I can upload another sizes.

Printed with Ultimaker 2
Layer thickness: 0.05
Shell Thickness: 1.5
No support needed
Basic clone of Synta-style dovetail finder brackets used by Celestron, Orion, Skywatcher, GSO and others. Works with the piggyback adapter I published here,

It need more 4-8 gimbal shock Absorber a.k.a damping ball
And 16 4mm screws

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4n1TFrx4kSU&feature=youtu.be

description.text:
Original idea come from : http://www.instructables.com/id/Repair-a-Broken-Ethernet-Plug/

But the problem is to find the suitable sized cable tie to proceed a reliable locking tab.

So my upgrade of this, is to print the locking tab part permitting to own the right size ;)

comments.text: what material to use?
comments.author: madmax2

comments.text: PLA is enough flexible if it's a little bit hot ;)
comments.author: madmax2

comments.text:
Of course the proper solution is to replace the cable; but where you've got a lead going behind a row of filing cabinets, through the ceiling, under a couple of desks and into the comms cab that's been there so long that someone has stacked half a ton of archived paperwork around it, you're not going to, are you.
Great idea - I'll be using this.
comments.author: AndyGadget

comments.text: Short of replacing the cable, crimping on a new connector would also solve the issue.  But just replacing the tab like this looks even easier.
comments.author: AndyGadget

description.text:
This is a remix of RealAbsurdity' Samsung S4 case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:99152 as well as RileZ33' WRX Sti Keyring Badge http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:590738 and singnow logo keychain http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32764

Case fits great - thank you for the source files.

I don't have any real cad programs, so I used tinkercad to modify the model (used the keyrings as cutouts).

Printrbot simple metal with grey PLA:
30 mm/s print speed
204 C temp
0.4 mm top/bottom thickness
100% infill
